posts.text: I have amassed a fleet of 14 3d printers, 11 of which are mine, printing PPE for the North Jersey/ NYC area. After 2319 shields printed and delivered I am having a hard time finding hospitals in my area that need it. Does anyone in the continuous United States know places that need them and have direct contact with them?

posts.text:
Our group has printed over 1k face shields over the past couple weeks...but now dentists are about to go back to work. The issue is they use loupes (magnification glasses) and most face shield designs don't protrude out from the face far enough to leave room for the glasses and headlights.
Anybody have any face shield designs that protrude a good distance from the face? I'm talking 3-4 inches...

posts.text:
Masks work to contain droplets generated during speech. Visualization.
As an infectious disease epidemiologist I must point out that it is likely that most transmission (except in the medical setting or very prolonged sharing of air space in an enclosed setting) is via virus-laden droplets, either through direct contact (inhaled or deposited into eyes or mouth) or indirect, when these droplets land and are transferred to eyes, nose, or mouth by hand contact. Droplets can be a spectrum of sizes but most are way larger than viral particles. If viral transmission were largely by aerosolized virus or virus contaminated aerosol-sized droplets, the epidemiologic pattern would be different than what we see and the R0, reproductive rate, would be considerably higher.
So, if all the population were to wear masks when out of the home, 100% of the time, pretty much regardless of the material and fit, and everyone washed their hands according to the WHO or CDC method, the virus would be vanquished.
NEJM.ORG
Visualizing Speech-Generated Oral Fluid Droplets with Laser Light Scattering | NEJM

posts.text:
Fabric experts: Visiting Nurse Association is in need of masks for patient use while showering to protect the Aides (who will be wearing surgical masks, there are not enough surgical masks for patients).
Would polyester/microfiber or polyester blend be better for this? I have medium weight woven bamboo something (sheets) that feels like microfiber and 60/40 poly cotton woven medium weight on hand.
And of course already cut two different weights/weaves of 100% cotton for inner and outer, but before I sew, thoughts?

posts.text:
So, I printed this updated version of the Montana Mask. It legit seals better than my surgical mask or any N95s I've used, on MY face at least. It needs very little filter material and the breathability seems to be good. But it takes about 3 and a half hours to print in a somewhat acceptable quality. Are these worth dedicating one of my printers to exclusively?
Here's the files: https://www.prusaprinters.org/prints/27959-montanamaskv10

posts.text: Hey. My husband and I came up with a small idea that seemed worth sharing. 😎 This is a flexible wire strip made by braiding garbage bag twist ties together, and then inserted into a simple cloth mask, so it fits a little tighter and more comfortably across our noses.

posts.text:
Hi. Is there anyone making these face shields with a visor that would be willing to make some for McLaren Hospital in Michigan. I have a couple nurse friends that are married and work at McLaren. Their mother/MIL is in ICU there. They need face shields. My son Nick Magolan is making these for several healthcare people but can’t keep up with the demand on his small printer. They gotten a few with the visor from my son like the one I posted below. He’s gotten the print time down to 2.5hrs. Anyone willing to help out?
THINGIVERSE.COM
DtM-v3.0 Face Shield PPE for COVID-19, Remix of Prusa RC2 by designthatmatters

posts.text:
My daughter’s 2nd grade Brownie Girl Scout Troop (in the Girl Scout Council of the Nation’s Capital) has decided to help make masks similar to N-95s to give to nursing home nurses on the front lines. The girls have the supplies to add elastic and padding, but they need masks printed on 3D printers. They haven’t had much success finding 3D printers in our community.
A father of one of the girls in the troop is an anesthesiologist at a local hospital and has been making the masks and using them with great success. He will help work with the girls virtually and all of this will be done by the girls individually in their own homes.
Any ideas of how to get masks printed? We need people willing to print a file we have. Working with
MAKETHEMASKS.COM
Make The Masks

posts.text: My research lab is currently exploring means to mass produce face shields and face masks. However, we are experiencing difficulties with obtaining supplies such as filters, transparencies, and elastic bands quickly. Could you guys help us with locating reliable suppliers for these materials? Thanks a lot!

posts.text:
Acknowledging there is a need everywhere (I'm near Boston, myself), please consider reaching out to hospitals, clinics, nursing homes, emergency management, etc in rural areas of the country.
They may not be national hotspots. But the populations are generally older, have higher incidences of underlying conditions, and in some cases- like my home county- they've got very few tests to give. The tests that are given are taking *weeks* to get results. It's a wildfire waiting to happen.
Meanwhile, hospital staff, emergency workers, nursing home workers are all still waiting for supplies that may/may not ever show up.
I'm in talks with my home county in rural KS about sending shields. From what I've been told, they've ordered shields but have no idea when/if they'll get them. This article suggests that they're likely to be outbid. My sense is this is representative of many rural counties.
I'm not suggesting to completely divert supplies away from cities. Rather consider giving a small portion to a rural area. Or whatever you're compelled to do. The impact could be huge.
Thank you.

KANSASCITY.COM
Kansas nearly last in COVID-19 testing, lacks ‘clout’ in bidding war for supplies

posts.text: My son is an ER nurse in Chicago and has asked me to sew him some surgical caps. Can anyone recommend a pattern appropriate for a home sewist. I have lots of fabric but no more elastic so I’m hoping to make something simple that ties behind the head. Thanks for your help.

posts.text:
Nina Shih
Yesterday at 1:15 AM ·
Johnny and I tested some materials' efficacy in filtering 0.3 - 10 μm particles with a particle counter.
https://sites.google.com/view/material-filter-testing/home
Website includes the latest updates and works best on desktop. The charts are interactive to reveal more details.
You can read more about our "quick & dirty" methodology here: https://github.com/jcl5m1/ventilator/wiki/Material-Filter-Testing
Please be careful with material used -- are they safe to be inhaled through; they do not contain fiberglass, ...
In addition to particle filtration efficacy, please test diy home made masks at home first to see how breathable they are. Please be careful if the material is not breathable -- do you feel lightheaded, disoriented, ...
If folks have recommendations on how to test pressure drop across fabric (breathability), we'd love to hear about it.
We are not professionals in this field, just DIY homebodies.

posts.text:
Mask sterilization project
Sean Ja‎Open Source COVID19 Medical Supplies - Washington
April 17 at 11:58 PM ·
Vapor Phase Hydrogen Peroxide test with cool mist humidifier. The goal was to see if a consumer grade vaporizer can produce enough vapor to fill a 12cu foot camber and produce condensation. This would demonstrate the delivery and application of vaporized H2O2 on Filtering facepiece respirators (FFRs). The system floods the chamber with vaporized H2O until the humidity level reached dew point, at which the vapor condenses on the materials in the chamber.
